title: Meta-Learning: Learn How to Learn
description: A foundational quest that teaches effective learning behaviors and mental models. Apply to any learning goal you already have on the platform.

steps.title: Choose a Learning Target
steps.description: Select any active or upcoming learning goal from your quests, skills, or create a new one.

conceptCard.title: Learning is skill-agnostic
conceptCard.body:
Learning works the same way across subjects. Languages, math, programming, philosophy, and music all rely on the same underlying processes.

By choosing a concrete learning target, you give your brain something specific to work on. The process you practice here will transfer to other skills later.

This quest is not about what you learn. It is about how you learn anything.

steps.title: Focused Session
steps.description: Complete a single focused learning session (20-30 minutes, distraction minimized, one clear objective).

conceptCard.title: Focused mode builds structure
conceptCard.body:
Focused attention is when you deliberately concentrate on one problem or idea. This is where you build initial understanding and form the raw pieces of knowledge.

Focused work feels effortful and slow. That is normal. If learning feels easy, you are often just recognizing information, not building it.

Focused mode is necessary, but it is not sufficient on its own.

steps.title: Diffuse Break
steps.description: Intentionally disengage: walk, shower, light physical task, rest. No content consumption required.

conceptCard.title: Insight comes from letting go
conceptCard.body:
When you step away, your brain continues working in the background. This relaxed state is often where connections form and insights appear.

Walking, resting, showering, or doing light physical tasks all help activate this mode. Consuming new content usually does not.

Learning improves when you deliberately alternate between focused effort and relaxed disengagement.

steps.title: Retrieval Attempt
steps.description: Without notes, write or record what you remember, what feels unclear, what you got wrong. Accuracy is not scored.

conceptCard.title: Trying to remember is what strengthens memory
conceptCard.body:
Actively trying to recall what you learned strengthens memory far more than rereading or reviewing notes.

Struggle during recall is a good sign. It means your brain is rebuilding the knowledge instead of passively recognizing it.

Getting things wrong here is useful information, not failure.

steps.title: Reflection
steps.description: Answer short prompts about what surprised you, what felt easy but wasn't, what felt hard but improved, and whether insight occurred after the break.

conceptCard.title: Awareness prevents false confidence
conceptCard.body:
Your brain is very good at feeling like it understands something when it does not. This is called an illusion of competence.

Reflection helps you notice gaps, confusion, and unexpected difficulty. It trains you to judge learning by performance, not comfort.

Good learners pay attention to what feels hard and unclear, not just what feels smooth.

steps.title: Spacing Check
steps.description: After at least 24 hours, revisit the topic briefly and note what persisted, what decayed, what re-clicked quickly.

conceptCard.title: Forgetting is part of learning
conceptCard.body:
Memory strengthens when learning is spread out over time. Revisiting material after forgetting has begun makes it more durable.

If everything feels familiar immediately, learning is shallow. If some things faded and need rebuilding, learning is working.

Spacing turns short-term understanding into long-term skill.

metadata.completionCriteria: All required artifact types exist for a single target + spacing check time gap is met
